sp.speaker: Xan.
sp.l: I'l be a hoſtage for him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: So will I.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: You are both priviledg'd by your deſerts
We cannot touch you, we'll have other perſons.

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.l: Come we'll oblige the Conſul to be friend us.
We'll take his word.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: No, we will have his Oath.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: You have my ſolemn Oath.

sp.speaker: Xan.
sp.l: 'Tis more than needs.
Great men, were there no Gods, would keep their words
In reverence to themſelves; but Gods there are,
Whom none needs rouſe by Oaths to witneſs Truth.
Now let me tell you, (if I can for grief
For I much honour you) if you return
Without a laſting Peace, which frees theſe Lands
From all thoſe ſeeds of War, your Garriſons,
You will return to a tormenting Death,
And all my power cannot ſave you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: Of all the torments I ſhall ſuffer here,
The Griefs of ſuch a noble Heart as yours
Will moſt afflict me; if you wou'd ſpare me,
Be ſparing of your ſelf; pity me not
Till I'm become a pitiful poor wretch,
Deſpoil'd of all my reſolution,
And made indeed a Captive by baſe fear.

sp.speaker: Xan.
sp.l: The good Gods graciouſly direct you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: And you moſt noble Spartan; of all men
I e're encounter'd, the moſt generous.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Oh! I'm afraid our head's loſt, oh! if they take my head, what ſhall I do.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: The Rabble are fine fellows to truſt to.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.p: Well I can ſay for my honour, I ever hated the vulgar. I have undone thouſands of 'em, and I never did one of 'em good in my life.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.p: Sir you have had the impudence to cheat Perſons o' Quality. If you had only cheated poor fellows, you ſhou'd have had a friend o' me.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: My ruine wou'd be great delight to me,
If by my fall Carthage were overwhelm'd.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: That it may be ſpite o' this great ſucceſs.
Though Regulus is taken Rome is not.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: I'll tell your Highneſs very excellent news,
The Romans burnt this day in our own Ports,
Above threeſcore of our beſt men of war. ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Ha! art thou ſure of that?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: I'm very ſure.
The Romans now may land what men they will;
If they don't take the Town I'gad I'l hang.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: But will they take the Town before we hang?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: That I can't ſay.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Nay if we hang, let who will have the Town. Well, I am horridly afraid to dye. I'd go to Prayers if I thought t' wou'd ſignify any thing.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.p: Whom wou'dſt thou pray to? thou haſt no Friends in Heaven, thou never mad'ſt the leaſt acquaintance there: thou haſt traded to all parts but Heaven.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I doubt none of us have any great ſtore of Friends in Heaven; if we had, they'd ne're ha' ſuffer'd us to come to this.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Right, therefore Heaven has no great Friend o' me.
Ha! I'm a fool to open thus my heart
To fools; who though they ſhould have honeſty
May be outwitted into knavery.
But now it is in vain to look my heart,
For all the dangerous ſecrets are gone out.
—Well, Sirs, what do you think? are we in danger?
I do not think we are; what have we done?
Much have we talk'd indeed, in merriment,
About I know not what, of this and that,
Of altering ſome Forms of Government.
But that was only matter of diſcourſe,
We cou'd not be in earneſt, for we know
'Twas wholly impracticable.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Do you hear.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: That ſhall not bring him off, he was in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Were not you ſo?

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: No, I abhor the thought.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: you mov'd him to't.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: A trick to try him.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Pox o' your tricks, you have noos'd me,
To ſave my neck I have been forc'd to make
Shameful Confeſſions.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: Well, y'are ſerv'd right, why wou'd you be a knave
And plot to take your Countries liberty.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: A knave? how cou'd I chuſe but be a knave,
Keeping ſuch knaviſh company as yours.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: 'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Ha! wrangling Gentlemen?
What, I believe y'are diſcompos'd by fear?
Fear nothing, for I ſay, what have we done?
Shew'd our Affection to the Commonwealth
In a miſtaken way? will they put men
To death, for being ſubject to miſtakes?
Then it will be a fault to be a man.
But do not fear, for I have one ſure Friend,
Money I mean, which ſhall buy all our pardons?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Oh! dear, Sir, will your Highneſs buy my pardon?

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Thine? what art thou to me? theſe are my Friends
And Gentlemen: thou art a barterer
Canſt traffique for thy ſelf; buy thy own head.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: And ſo I wou'd at reaſonable rates.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: De'e hear? de'e hear? we have been ſilly knaves,
I wou'd I had all my confeſſion back.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: W'ave been too haſty, I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: I muſt keep up the ſpirits of theſe fools.
Be merry Sirs; I warrant you your lives.
Who's there?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Bring in my Wine and Muſic
Here is ſincere Wine.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: And here are ſophiſticated Knaves, pity they ſhou'd be put together.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Come, ſing us a Catch.

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: Down with your ſprightly Wine, boys,
Down with your ſprightly Wine, boys,
For a Traveller bound,
To the Stygian Lake,
A Brimmer Crown'd
With ſparkling Sack,
Is the beſt, is the beſt Divine, boys.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: If the Wine be not ſound,
No Falſehood is found
In a Bowl well crown'd;
And it drowns all our Sorrow and Sin:
And by the help of a Bowl,
From the World we may rowl,
More merrily than we came in.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: With his Flames and his Flams,
And his horrible Shams,
How the Church-man damns
The little poor Villains and Whores;
But the great who by Power,
Whole Nations devour,
He merrily crowns and adorns.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: If your Sence you'll reſign,
Give it up to good Wine,
But to no Divine,
For his Viſions are frightful and ſad;
But the Viſions in Bowls,
Make jovials Souls,
More merrily, merrily mad.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: To what Regious we fly,
None know when they die,
Any more than I,
To be certain of heavenly Bliſs;
The few Moments I ſtay,
I by Night and by Day,
Will merrily revel and kiſs.
Down with your ſprightly Wine, boys &c.

sp.l: Enough, be gone.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: I wonder Giſgon your fine Perſian Wife
Comes not to viſit you.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: I wonder more
She does not come to kiſs your Highneſs Hands.
For ſhe has brought with her from Perſia
Her Country Adoration of all Princes.

sp.speaker: Lady within.
sp.l: Where's my Husband?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Hark! I hear her voice.
sp.stage: Enter a Perſian Lady ſupported by her Women.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Oh! Princely Sir, I humbly kiſs the Earth
Y'are pleas'd to honour, with your ſacred Feet.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Oh! Madam, you are not in Perſia.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No Sir, I wou'd you were, your Royal Blood
Wou'd not there meet this profanation.
Now Sir, ſhall I implore your Princely leave
To have ſome Conference with your Slave my Husband?
Oh! are you there Sir.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Ha! I am afraid
She has been told I'm turning an informer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You are a worthy perſon.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Did not I bring much Honour to your Bed?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Madam you did.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Much Fortune too?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Have not I kept the Honour which I brought?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Madam you have.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Have not I manag'd too
Your Fortune with the utmoſt care and wiſdom?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Exquiſite Wiſdom.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Of your perſon too
Have I not been moſt tender?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Moſt obliging:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Then why have you been a baſe man to me?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo, (aſide) in what reſpect moſt noble Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: In ſuch an odious way I loath to name it.
This Valiant Gentleman, this Noble Spark,
Has ſold his Honour, for vile ſhameful life.
He has ſubmitted cowardly to confeſs
Your Highneſs plotted to be Monarch here.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Oh! dog! can I not get him near the wall,
That I may brain him? (aſide) have you done this Giſg • n?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, I have, and Sir you know 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Say it be true; have you not told me, Sir, he has a right to reign? that he's deſcended from King Strato.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.p: Well, let him be deſcended from fifty Kings, I don't care. I'll not be a ſlave to him, nor to any Prince upon earth.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Oh! Madam, it was all but railery.
And he was one that ſtarted firſt the jeſt;
Now by his fooling I loſe life and honour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: His fooling, Sir? his cowardly treachery.
What e're you were, he was in earneſt Sir.
He has a thouſand times boaſted to me,
What Honours he ſhou'd have, when you were King.
Then, though your Highneſs be moſt innocent,
And will eſcape (I hope and beg the Gods)
He ſhall dye; I'll ſwear he is a Traytor,
Double, falſe, both to the Prince and People.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Oh! Whore!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: So is that Reverend perſon too.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: And has the Prieſt been dabbling.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Deeply Sir.
He has been at his Revelations;
His Commentaries, Sir, on your dark Text.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: I'll take him by the beard, and wring his head off

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: Well, Sir, I did as I was bound in conſcience.
I'll not betray my Countries Liberty.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: No—then thou't not a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ah! fooliſh men, they might have liv'd and dy'd
With glory, and have got a thouſand Friends.

sp.speaker: Hia.
sp.l: They'd ha' done us much good when we were hang'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: More good than infamous baſe life will do.
Now all will ſpit upon you. I abhor you,
Who lately ador'd you, and reſolv'd to do
The greateſt things for you.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: What cou'd you do?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Oh! Madam can you do us any kindneſs?
Oh! if you can I will preſent your Honour,
I will give any thing for my head in reaſon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Hold thy tongue fool, I think not of ſuch fellows.
But for my Husband and his Reverence too,
I wou'd have done what had amaz'd the world;
If they had done as great men ought to do.
I'd have convey'd 'em through the Town in pomp,
In ſpite of all the Senate.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Through the Town?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes when your glorious Martrydom was paſt,
I wou'd ha' crown'd you ſuch Funerals—

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Pox o' your Funerals.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: Mind your own Funerals;
Vex not your head with ours.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Oh! Madam bury 'em dead or alive,
Or the corrupted Rogues will breed a peſt.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I cannot ſerve his Reverence as I wou'd
And he deſerves; but it is in my power
To do my Husband juſtice, I'll right him.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: She'l be the death of me.
I muſt retard her while I get my Pardon.
I have conſider'd on't—I would retract
My confeſſion, and rather dye than live
In all the ſhame I've brought upon my ſelf,
But I'm afraid they'l torture me to death.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Oh! I've ſo much Power with the great men.
Be you a noble valiant Gentleman
One I may own and love. Dye like a Hero
For this great high-born Prince, I'll undertake
The State ſhall not torment a man I love.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: She is a whore to the whole Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll get you any kind of death you fancy.
And for his Reverence too, if he deſire it.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: I do not fancy any kind of death.
If you do Madam take your fill of it.
Poyſon or hang your ſelf, and if you like it
Come tell us ſo, and Madam we'll be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis well—great Sir, I humbly take my leave
With infinite concernment for your danger.
I wou'd ha' ſacrificed my Husband for you,
With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: I do believe it Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Or my own life.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: You much oblige me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I take my leave in great confuſion.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: She'd have ſacrific'd me.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: Theſe women tamper here with State affairs,
And hang their Husbands, I'll be hang'd by no body.
I'm Heavenly mettal and belong to Gods,
And I will keep their Plate from batterry.
Troth Batto, I have done your buſineſs too.
I've let the Councel know your villany.
Not only trade with Romans, but conſpire
To ſet a King over the Commonwealth,
And take away our Liberties and Laws?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Oh! horrible! did you not move me to't?

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: Only to try you; I had heard of you.
I'm watchman for the Public; 'tis my Office
To have my Eye and Ear in every place,
And knock at every door. When I mov'd you,
I knock'd, and found a Knave within your boſom.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: And ſo you'd hang me?

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: I've endeavour'd it.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Well, and I've endeavour'd to hang you.
I've let the Councel know your Villany.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: Ha! have you ſo? Well ſee who ſhall have moſt credit.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Nay none of us I think will have much credit.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: So, ſo, the Rogues are hanging one another.
If ever a turn comes, I'll hang you all.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: Let a turn come; I fear not you or death,
For death will only change my vehicle.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: My Lord, here are ſome Senators from the Senate,
To ſpeak with your Highneſs

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: To take my head; I'm loſt. Wait on 'em in

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: My Lord, the Senate ſends to beg your Highneſs
To be Protector o' the Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Protector, Sir?

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: The Spartan General
Uſurps upon the State, he forc'd the Senate
To releaſe Regulus on his Parole.
The Common People think they are betray'd,
And have requir'd the Senate to free you,
And give you power, that you may puniſh him.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Sir, I'm unfit for Power, theſe Gentlemen
Have accus'd me of very horrid Treaſons.

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.l: They'r not believ'd but look'd on as defamers;
And order'd to be kept in cloſe confinement.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Oh! brave! oh! brave!

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: Oh! curſe on evidencing!

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Now Raſcals!—Keeper, put theſe men in ſetters.
Now Noble Senators, I'll wait on you,
To my moſt honourable Lords the Senate.

div.head: SCENE the Roman Camp.
div.stage: Enter on one ſide o' the Stage Metellus, Lepidus, and other Roman Commanders, on the other ſide Regulus.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Oh! Conſul!

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Brave Metellus! brave friends all!
De'e weep? nay then it ſeems you are ſubdued.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Who ever ſaw ſuch an amazing change?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Does it amaze you to ſee fortune change?
The wonder wou'd be greater ſhou'd ſhe fix.
She takes my freedom to maintain her own.
Remove your Eye from fortune my dark part,
And fix it on my ſelf, who ſtill remain
Not only unconquer'd, but invincible.
Yet o're victorious Carthage I'll triumph.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Oh! Sir! then have you terms for liberty?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: My liberty depends not on their will,
'Tis true, the freedom of my body does.
But that is born a ſlave, by nature bound
To ſerve the mind, a time prefixt by fate
And then turn'd over to new bonds in death.
Of this poor vaſſal I take little care.
How free my mind is, you ſhall ſoon perceive.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: I tremble for him.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Carthage to releaſe
This Body, (which can never be releas'd
From vaſſallage to ſufferings, and death)
Asks the refunding all our Victories.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Agreed! one Regulus is worth 'em all.
For he'll regain 'em all.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: You ſhall not give
The ſmalleſt link out o' that golden Chain.
It ſetters Carthage now, but if once broke
Carthage may ſcape, ariſe, nay enſlave Rome.
I come to rule your dangerous love to me,
Which I fear more than Carthaginian Racks;
For theſe can give me but ſome painful hours
Which glory will allay, and death will end.
But you wou'd torture me with lingring ſhame,
Got by a treacherous and cowardly peace.
Then as your Conſul, I command you all,
Give Carthage no more peace, than this ſhort truce.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: And what becomes o' you?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I muſt return.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Oh! joyful news.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Sir, you return to dye.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: It may be ſo.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: To a tormenting death.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: It may be ſo, my word and oath are paſt,
And nothing do I fear, like breach o' faith.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: A glorious man.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Will you forſake your friends,
To periſh by your barb'rous enemies?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I do not periſh, if my honour lives;
But if I ſtay ſhall not my body dye?
Then ſhall I loſe the honour I can keep,
To preſerve life, which is not i' my power?
By keeping faith, o're Carthage I triumph,
A Roman Ghoſt will triumph over her.
Not by ſhort pomp which blazes but ſome hours;
My triumph ſhall go on, from age to age,
While Rome ſhall ſtand, which ſhall the longer ſtand
For my example of unſhaken Faith,
For what Foundation to a State like Faith?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Sir, I'm the leſs amaz'd at what I hear,
For all your life has been with wonders fill'd.
But I have not ſo great a heart as yours
I cannot let you go.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: He ſhall not go;
I will bring all the Army to his feet.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Is't poſſible? I do command you ſtay.
Perform your duties both to Rome and me,
Let Rome have Carthage, and leave me to Heaven.
Metellus why de'e wrong your ſelf and me?
Your Spirit equals mine, and for the World,
You wou'd not have me leave this glorious path.
Like Romans now receive my laſt adieus.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: He ſhall not go, his Troops ſhall ſtop his way.
Now take your leaves.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Oh! Sir! what you reſolve
Has ſo much glory in't, I envy you.
But I muſt pity thoſe, whom you forſake,
My ſelf, your Children, my poor Fulvia.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Metellus be aſſur'd, thoſe you have nam'd,
Are dear to me, as they can be to you,
But Generals muſt diſcipline their thoughts.
The honor of the Gods and good of Rome
Muſt firſt command; next them I rank my friends,
Theſe have o're me ſo great authority
I'm jealous o' my weakneſs, and their power;
And dare not truſt my ſelf with ſeeing 'em.
I'll ne're ſee Fulvia more.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Not ſee her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Oh! no, an enterview will raiſe our griefs
To ſuch a tumult, 'twill not become me
To be ſeen in it. I'll ſerenely part,
And ſo retain my greatneſs to the laſt;
And this may leſs harm her.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Oh! Sir, ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Then I muſt fly, I cannot ſtay with her.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: The Conſul! Sir, the Conſul! where is he?
A minutes abſence more I cannot bear.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Oh! my unruly griefs will betray all.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: You ſigh, nay more you ſtrive to ſmother tears.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: No you miſtake.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I do not; Sir, I ſee't.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Your fears impoſe on you.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Convince me of it,
And let me ſee the Conſul.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Wait awhile.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I periſh then.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Y' are raſh, command your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: You muſt, he's buſied now in a great work,
The greateſt that was e're deſign'd by Man.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oh! what? and where?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Be not inquiſitive.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: Oh! why Sir, why? ſhall I not have a ſhare
In all his Fortunes?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Ay, too much poor Girl.
Let it ſuffice to know, his aims are now
Above what mortal Man ever attain'd.
And he will reach his aims now, ſeek no more.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I muſt, I muſt enquire, I cannot reſt;
This is all darkneſs and confuſion.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Oh! Madam! Madam! ſave the Conſul's Life.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Now the dire Myſtery begins t' unvail.
I'm dying, ſpeak whilſt I have Life to hear.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: He cannot make an honorable peace,
So he is only come to command war;
Now to keep faith with faithleſs enemies,
Returns to dye.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Y'ave ſtruck me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Fly, Madam, or you'll never ſee him more.
His Army at the preſent bar his way,
But all their force will, without you, be vain.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: My reaſon, ſence and life, before me fly;
The Conſul will enjoy his cruel wiſh,
Nothing of mine will ever reach him more,
Unleſs my ſhreiks cut through the wounded air,
Or Winds hurl to him my torn ſcatter'd hair.

div.stage: SCENE Continues. Regulus appears beſet by Lepidus, an Augur, all the Army; who in ſuppliant Poſtures ſurround him.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: WHO has betraid me thus, and brought my Troops
To beſiege me?

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Sir, I confeſs, 'twas I.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Y' are grateful Lepidus, I advanced you
To honor, you'd ſink me to the loweſt ſhame;
Make me appear a Coward, and be forſworn.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Well, Sir, we have not ſworn you ſhall return,
We are not perjur'd if we hinder you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Yes but you are, y' are ſworn to obey me.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: We may oppoſe you without Perjury,
If you deſtroy your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I ſave myſelf,
When I am falſe, I'm Regulus no more,
But a foul Spectre, which in little time
You'll hate and loath, whatever you think now.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Sir, this perhaps might force you from our hands,
If y' only went to die, for then you went
To the good Gods; you go to Furies now,
Who will torment you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Not beyond my ſtrength.
I've got this profit by calamity,
That I have learnt to bear calamity.
I never did believe it was an evil,
But now I do not think it troubleſome.
Miſery by uſe into our nature grows.
I by enduring pains will torture them,
And burn them with their own infernal rage.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: But, Sir, you'll alſo torture your dear Friends,
We dare not let you go.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: How ſhall I ſcape?
But the Proconſul comes, he'll do me right.
Sir, ſet me free from my diſtracted Friends,
Who would take from me more than Carthage can,
My Honor, Innocence, and their own Love;
For will they love me when I'm infamous?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Sir, ſomething ſo divine appears in you,
I proſtrate even my reaſon to your will.
Sir, if you wou'd reſolve to ſtay with us,
No earthly power ſhall take you from our hands;
But if you will return, I offer up
My ſelf, my Child, as Victims to your will,
For be aſſur'd we periſh, Sir, with you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I periſh if I ſtay, then ſet me free.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: I'll do you then this diſmal ſervice, Sir,
If I am able; but I doubt it much:
I hardly can believe the Legions,
Which oppoſe your commands, will obey mine.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I've thought upon a way—a word—give out,
Carthage has given me my mortal bane;
And in a ſence it has.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: A fatal truth!
I will do't, Sir, Pray Gentlemen draw near.
Follow no longer your miſtaken Love,
It leads you to no purpoſe from your way.
The Carthaginians have the Conſul faſt,
They've given him his death.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: What? poyſon'd him?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: They have his life, 'tis theirs do what you can;
They've torn it to a wretched Remnant now,
Not worth his keeping, therefore give it 'em,
It is the price of their Damnation:
And let him have the glory he deſires.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Oh! treacherous Murderers!

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Nay you trouble him.
Take hence your griefs, the Conſul has enow,
Go, throw 'em on his bloody Enemies.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: The Villains are too few for revenge.
And, oh! too vile to recompence our loſs;
The Carthaginian Nation cannot do't.
Oh! Conſul! ſince we muſt not hope for you,
And your ſtay here reprieves your Murderers,
We will releaſe you, to releaſe our ſelves
To our juſt vengeance.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Now I know you all.
I was afraid I had loſt all my Friends;
That Punick air breath'd Punick ſouls in you,
And that you ſlighted Faith; which I believe
No Roman does, except a Roman Prieſt.
Mourn not for me, for that implys I'm fallen,
Rather calamity falls under me.
Applaud my happy fortunes, for I go
In triumph to a higher Capitol,
And more magnificent than that in Rome;
One in the Heavens, where living Jove reſides.
True, I muſt firſt put off my fleſh by death,
But that I with as ſmall concern can do,
As men do Sandals at a Temple gate.
Now Friends farewel, thank you for all your Love,
And when I am in Carthage, ſtorm the Town.
Now, Sir, thank you for an immortal life,
For you have open'd me the way to it;
And at no ſmall expences to your heart.
Oh! Fulvia! there's my laſt great agony.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Sir, I have eas'd you of ſome part of it;
I met her flying t'ee, and ſtopp'd her way;
But might have ſpar'd the labor, for, alas!
Her ſorrow often flung her dead on earth.
I left her ſenceleſs in her womens arms,
You may eſcape her now. Oh! no! ſhe comes,
Comes like a Torrent, there's no ſtopping her.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Nay then, what ſufferings have I to bear?
I fear my ſtrength, and dare not meet her Eyes.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oh! Conſul! Conſul! what have you decreed?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Daughter, away.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I cannot, cannot, Sir.
Pray pardon me, I'm not in my own power.
Oh! Conſul! will y' abandon all your friends
For Slavery and Death, tormenting Death?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: He's bound by Oath.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Was he not ſo to me?
And by a Thouſand Oaths, he had no right
To give himſelf away without my leave:
He's true to Murderers, and falſe to me.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Dear Fulvia, calm your ſelf, and uſe your reaſon,
You'll find I've acted as became a Man,
Who durſt pretend to ſuch a heart as yours.
Should ſuch a Man betray the Rights of Rome
To ſave his life?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Your death will ruine Rome,
And me, and all the World.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: No, Fulvia;
By dying I preſerve the Rights of Rome,
Advance her Glory, and mine, and therefore yours.
Now Rome will be my lofty Monument,
'Twill ſtand upon my Tomb, where I ſhall reſt,
In a Bed fit for him whom Fulvia loves.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Where ſhall I reſt when Regulus is dead?
You take no care for me.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: Will you not reſt
In my repoſe? can our united hearts
Have any joys, or griefs, both do not feel?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I do not know your heart, but I believe
Your griefs afflict me more, than they do you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Too much, too much.
More than a Slave, as I am, can deſerve.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: You are my Lord; more dear (if poſſible)
To me than ever: by your fall my heart
Is greatly bruis'd, and tend'rer than before;
More ſenſible of Sorrow, and of Love.
Then pity me, for my ſake, go with me.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I dare not do't, becauſe I love you more,
Than to permit your ſorrow to deceive you.
You ſeek to take with you, a Slave, a Coward,
A Thief, a Murderer; all this I muſt be,
If I return not. I ſhall break my Oath,
To ſteal my Freedom from the gallant Spartan
Who truſted me; and if I break my truſt
I expoſe him to all my Sufferings,
And perhaps prove his bloody Murderer.
Would you have ſuch a Villain as this with you?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oh! theſe are arts to hide your want of Love,
You love me not, ne're lov'd, you have deceived me.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Now Daughter you are too importunate.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oh! by my Love, I know he does not love,
I for no Joy on Earth could part with him;
He flies from me to Torments, and the Grave.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: No, no, to Juſtice, Piety, Renown.

sp.speaker: Ful
sp.l: He is unjuſt, I have a right in him,
I never did, I never will renounce.
To take himſelf from me is Robbery
And cruel Murder, it will be my death,
And this he knows; but he regards not me,
He can be tender of his Enemies,
And not of me.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Oh! Madam! ſay not ſo.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Go, go to Carthage, let her have her right,
And I'll have mine.
I've title to partake whate're is yours.
It ſeems Chains, Miſery and Death are yours,
And all the forrune you have left your ſelf.
Well I'll to Carthage wi' you, and have my ſhare.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: To Carthage?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Do you think I dare not do't?
Yes valiant Conſul, I in ſome reſpects,
In reſolution will tranſcend even you.
You are divine, above all ſence of ill;
I'm a weak Woman, I have tender ſence,
I can feel torments, yet I'll ruſh upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sweet Fulvia, hear me.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oh! I love too much
To hear and ſee you; would I lov'd it leſs,
My miſery and misfortune would be leſs.
Would I had never lent an Ear to you.
Yet you would now be heard. What ſhould I hear,
Bloody Decrees againſt yourſelf and me?
Oh! I have heard too much, too much o'them.
And why ſhould you expect I ſhould hear you?
You regard not my Love, my Tears, my Blood.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Hold Fulvia, hold! you harm a dying Friend,
Who dyes for you and me, and for all Rome.
Why ſay you Miſery is all the fortune
Of this great Man? is Glory of no price?
Are you a Roman, and want ſence of glory?
All Ages will adore this wondrous Man,
Whom you wrong heavily. See, ſee, I ſwear,
Sh' as wrung Tears from him; now but that I know,
What thou haſt ſaid proceeds from raving Love,
For this great Sacriledge I'd ſtrike thee dead.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Oh! Sir! you now commit the cruelty
You charge her with, you wound a wounded heart.
I know her heart is bleeding now for me,
And what ſhe ſays comes from her pain, not her;
She is moſt kind in what ſhe ſeems unkind.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Inndeed I am, and though your Love were loſt.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Oh ſay it not.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I do not think it is;
But if it were, yet I muſt love you ſtill,
Nay in calm thoughts adore you, and believe
You are too excellent, that's all your fault,
And my misfortune was, I lov'd too high.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Now Daughter you judge well, and do him right,

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oh! 'twas my madneſs wrong'd him, and not I.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I know't ſweet Fulvia, and can I be falſe
To ſo much love! before I knew you lov'd,
I lov'd you ſo, that you were my chief aim.
In ſeeking Glory I ſought chiefly you.
I fought for you, and now I dye for you,
By glorious Death more to deſerve your Love;
And therefore be more lov'd; for if I dye
To keep my Faith with mortal Enemies,
Oh! think how firm my heart muſt be to you.
But ſhou'd I poorly live by breach of faith,
I ſhould for ever loſe you in both worlds;
You'd ſhun me here with ſcorn, and after death,
I for my Perjury ſhou'd ſhine in ſhades,
While you wou'd ſhine in Heaven; there is a Heaven.
This ſhred of Life cannot be all the Web,
Nature has wrought to cover divine Spirits;
There is a Heaven becauſe there's miſery.
The divine Power ever bleſt and good,
Made not the World for an ill natur'd jeſt,
To ſport himſelf in pains of thoſe he made.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: True, but for Heaven what muſt you endure?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: No more than what you cou'd endure for me.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oh! that I might, I'd run to it with joy.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Then cannot I for you, ſweet Fulvia?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: So, y'ave prepared balm for the parting blow;
And that you may the better bear it to.
Take from each other your entangling Eyes.
I'll interpoſe and hide 'em—now, my Lord.
sp.stage: [Metellus goes between, Regulus offers to go. Fulvia holds him.]

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Hold, hold, I cannot, will not let you go.
I'll loſe my arms before I'll loſe my hold.
I know what you reſolve is glorious;
But I'm a Woman, and my Love prevails;
And the more brave you are, the more I love,
And the leſs able am to part with you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Oh! I am in a tempting dangerous ſnare.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Nay do not grieve, you cannot ſcape from me,
I ſhall releaſe you ſoon, my heart will break.
sp.stage: [The Ghoſt of Apamia riſes, Fulvia ſhreiks, and falls in her Womens Arms.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: She ſhreiks and dies! her heart is broke indeed,
Poor Girl!

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Oh! now I ſee what made her ſhriek,
A frightful Meſſenger is come for me.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: From Carthage?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: From the dead; 'tis my dead Wife.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: I perceive nothing dead, but my poor Child;
I hope ſhe's dead, life would afflict her now.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Take notice Heaven, what we all endure
Only for Vertue. This one ſweet laſt touch
Of this fair hand is the only recompence,
I ſhall receive for all I loſe on Earth.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: I'll ſee you to the Lines then take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oh! he is gone! he is for ever gone.
Fond tears be gone, ſuch vain and vulgar ſorrow
Does not become the grave of Regulus.
I'll ſtrew his Tomb with Carthaginian Ruines.
And this whole Nation for his bloody death,
Shall weep to death in blood—Ho, Lepidus.
Where is your Conſul?

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: He is near the Walls.
Where Thouſands of us will be preſently;
We are preparing for him a revenge.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Come follow me—
I'm now your Conſul, his Soul lives in me.
We'll bury Carthage ſo, that where it ſtood,
In future ages ſhall to few be known;
Some ſhall believe here never was a Town.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Moſt noble Senators, will you be pleas'd
To tell my honorable Lords, the Senate,
I'll only give ſome neceſſary orders
About their Service, then attend their Pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: We ſhall, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: I fee the Senates craft;
I'm only us'd like Phyſic for a need;
With loathing forc'd upon 'em, and the wiſh'd
Effect once wrought, I ſhall be flung away.
For Commonwealths cannot bear glorious men,
By the confeſſions of the Prieſt and Giſgon
I am in danger, but I'll try to quaſh 'em.
I order'd the confeſſing Gentlemen
Should be brought to me.
1. They are come, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: How the Rogues look and tremble, for my ſport?
I'll let their terrors worry 'em a while.

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: What will he do with us?

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: I do not know.
I'm under dreadful conſternation.

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: How? are y' afraid of death, now it is come?
I've heard you crow over death on your own Dunghil.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Oh! no profaneneſs in affliction, pray.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Oh! now the wind ſits there, y'ave a ſore Throat;
At other times your ſwallow's large enough.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: The Raſcals wrangle; and how pale they look?
The Prieſt there, has a face juſt like a Gooſe,
White every where, except about his Bill.
His Noſe is faithful to the dye, Wine gave it.
Well, now my grave, my cheating face goes on.
Oh! Gentlemen! I love and honor you.
Come to my arms.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: What's this? come to his arms?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Has he not got an engine there to flaſh us?

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: You lov'd the Commonwealth above my life,
Or your own credit; you are honeſt men.
You play'd the part of Spies, oh, you did well.
To tell you truth, it was a part I play'd.
I was a Spy on you.

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: Indeed, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Indeed. But you had one great quality
Moſt fit for Spies, of which I had no ſhare.
You ſcorn thoſe ſcorns which always are the vales
Of that unlucky Office. I confeſs,
I was kept under by the fear of ſhame,
And partly by ſome tenderneſs for you:
I love you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: Your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: Your Excellencies very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: A noble Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: A gallant Man!

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Beſides I found no great neceſſity
To do you harm; when I had power enough
To hinder you from doing the State harm.
But that I never meant to wrong the State,
I ſwear before the Gods. Do not I know,
It is impoſſible to be King here?
Speak your minds Gentlemen, you never thought
I was ſo fooliſh as to be in earneſt;
And ſtake my life at a ſure loſing game?

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: We knew not what to think of your Highneſs,
We acted as our Conſciences directed.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Oh! You did very well, y' are honeſt men.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I can ſwear for your Highneſs, you never ſaid one word to me, of being King.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Th'aſt done me right, ſo muſt theſe Gentlemen,
Or they will bring great guilt upon themſelves:
For Gentlemen, had you thought me in earneſt,
You'd have inform'd, when firſt you knew my guilt.
Inſtead o'that, you never let it go,
Till you cou'd purchaſe your own lives by it:
For, Sirs, can you deny the fear of death
Had not a mighty hand in this great work?

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: It had a little finger in't indeed.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Well Gentlemen, y'ave ſerv'd the Senate well.
Now he that is an entire honeſt Man
Does right to all Men; clear my innocence,
Then both the Senate and myſelf muſt love you,
For having ſerv'd us both moſt honeſtly.
And let me tell you, it is in my power
To raiſe or ruine you; which I ſhall do,
According as I find you good or bad.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: We had beſt ſtick to him, he's a great man

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Ay, and a very devilliſh cunning Man.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Ay, and an honeſt man for ought I know,
He never ſaid a word to me of being King.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: This Fellows evidence too will miſchief us.
—We'll ſerve your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: You are honeſt men.
Come we will to the Senate, they are ſate.

div.head: SCENE The Senate Houſe. The Senate ſitting, the Pretor in the Chair.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: Moſt Honorable, Venerable Lords;
I have an infinite deſire to ſerve you.
It is my ſole ambition, whatſoe're
Some Men may tell you: but, alas! my arm
Is wither'd by a blaſt, theſe Gentlemen
Have blown upon me; I muſt do 'em right.
They have inform'd, I talk'd of being King.
'Tis true, I did; they ſtarted firſt the Talk.
The Apparition, of ſo great a Treaſon,
So ſcar'd me, that I knew not what to anſwer.
I ſoon reflected, I ſhould better ſerve
The State by humoring theſe Gentlemen,
To find how far they'd dug in ſuch a Mine;
Then I ſhould do, by making 'em in fri •• ts
Conceal their works. But that I ever went
One ſtep with 'em, or gave 'em cauſe to think,
I aim'd at being King, I do deny;
And they have prov'd by hiding long the Treaſon.
But I commend 'em that they e're diſcover'd it,
And humbly beg noble Rewards for 'em.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: What ſay you Gentlemen? d'ee think my Lord
Meant to be King?

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: We know not what he meant.
We did diſcover it for fear he meant it;
But were not haſty in diſcovery,
Becauſe it was not plain to us he meant it.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: It ſeems he would, and he would not be King.
Why, Sir, you baffle your own evidence.
What ſays your Reverence to this affair?

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.l: I do deſire, as it becomes my Coat,
To have my name and conſcience without ſpot.
I fear'd his Highneſs was ambitious;
To feel his pulſe, I mov'd him to be King.
His Highneſs did accept the tempting proffer.
To do my Duty to the State I told it.
But I muſt do his Highneſs right;
He ne're advanc'd one ſtep in th' affair,
Or gave us cauſe to think he did approve it.
So I have conſcientiouſly diſcharg'd
My Duty to the Senate, and his Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: That is to ſay, y'ave play'd the Knave with both;
And with yourſelf the Fool, as you ſhall find.
What ſays, that Citizen?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: An't pleaſe your Honor,
His Highneſs never ſaid one word to me
Of being King. All I know of th' affair
Was from his Reverence; he told me indeed,
His Highneſs had a fancy to be King:
And alſo ſaid, if I would help his Highneſs
To keep a correſpondence with the Romans,
If by the Romans help he got the Crown,
I ſhou'd be ſure of very rich rewards.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: So, ſo, they've been diſpoſing all our Money.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: And all our Lives; the Romans muſt ha' come.
By all y'ave ſaid, y'ave fairly clear'd my Lord,
And charg'd yourſelves. I think 'tis fit they die.
What ſays your Lordſhips?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Ay, ay, hang 'em, hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: How? hang us?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Go, away with 'em, and hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, will you let us be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: What wou'd you have me do? oppoſe the Senate?

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: We are all fop'd here, fop'd out of our lives.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Oh! dear! I cannot dye! I cannot dye!

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Thou canſt do nothing elſe, thou dyeſt with fear.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: I am not prepared to dye!

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: No, Sir, nor I.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: I have my Religion yet to chuſe.

sp.speaker: Giſg.
sp.l: I have my hanging Equipage to make.
I deſire to hang like a Man o' Quality.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Dye piouſly, that's the beſt Equipage.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: They'r not content with hanging; torture 'em.

sp.speaker: Giſ.
sp.l: Hold, hold! my Lords! we beg we may be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: That's a ſad thing! muſt we intreat a hanging?

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.l: Away with 'em, and hang 'em preſently.
sp.stage: Hiarbas, Giſgon, and Batto are guarded off.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: So Traytors now will have a care of me.
For I out-match 'em all at their own art.
Now venerable Lords my hands are free
To guard you.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: To deſtroy us all, we know you.
sp.stage: [A Noiſe of a Multitude, crying Juſtice, Justice.]

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: My Lords, the Traytors are all executed;
And at their deaths conjured the Multitude,
If any thing they had was precious to 'em,
With utmoſt ſpeed to quell Lord Aſdrubal,
Or he'd be King, and they'd be all undone▪
So all the Town are at your gates, to beg.
You'll fling him to their mercy.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: We will do't.
Guards ſeize Lord Aſdrubal, and carry him out
To be diſpos'd as the good People pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Aſd.
sp.l: As the baſe Rabble pleaſe, your dirty Lords.
You take my life for what you ought to thank me.
I ſhou'd have honor'd you by being your King.
Had I been King, y'ad ſerv'd a high born Prince.
Now you are Vaſſals to a naſty Rout.
Confound your Commonwealth! Confound it▪ no.
Continue it Heaven! that there may never live
A great Man here. In a baſe Commonwealth,
Merit is Treaſon; a great Man oppreſſes!
His little Maſters, by out-ſhining 'em.
I'm your Oppreſſor now, your Tyrant now,
Fear of me tortures you; I give you Laws.
Shake and look pale! you do—Obedient Cowards!
While I have Life, I've Empire in my frown,
And in my courage a bright awful Crown.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Why? what a thundring Tyrant had this been
Upon a Throne, when he is thus in Fetters?

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: 'Tis well we're rid of him; wou'd with this eaſe
We cou'd be freed from the bold dangerous Spartan.
The Traytor Aſdrubal has told ſome truth.
A Commonwealth bears no imparity.
A great Man is a Tumor, is a Diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: My Lords, the Roman Conſul is return'd.
The Spartan General attends,
With his great Priſoner, to know your pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Go bring 'em in.
sp.stage: Enter Xantippus ſad and dejected, Regulus bold and lively.
sp.l: Ha! What means this? our General is ſad.
Which is the Conqueror, and which the Captive?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Have you forgotten me ſo ſoon my Lords?

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: No, but you come with the air of a Triumpher.
Your Conqueror there comes like a mournful Priſoner.
Has he ſubdued you General ſince he went?

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: Yes, and your Lordſhips too, he has o'recome,
In a more dreadful battle with his Friends,
Than e're he fought with your moſt valiant Troops;
Their griefs had ſharper edges than your Swords:
He has o'recome 'em all, and now returns
To triumph here, and if I might prevail,
He ſhou'd triumph, and be led round the Town;
With Lawrels crown'd; t' encourage all your Subjects
To do for Carthage what he did for Rome;
For if you honor vertue in a Foe,
What may a great deſerving Friend expect?

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Is this true, Regulus? have you brought war?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I have done Juſtice both to Rome and you.
What Roman Valor got, I have preſerv'd,
And hither brought myſelf your right by war.

sp.speaker: 1. Sen.
sp.l: Be crown'd with Lawrels? torn with red hot Pincers.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: Be torn!

sp.speaker: 2. Sen.
sp.l: Be torn. Go fetch the Torturers.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: Touch him that dares, he is my right.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Once more,
Out-brave us all in our own Senate-houſe?
Xantippus know we are provided for you.
Our fond confiding in your faith and honor,
Expos'd us lately to your inſolence.
Now we have fifty Thouſand Men in arms,
Affront us now, no Spartan ſhall eſcape.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: Behave yourſelves like Men, and we'll obey you.
But if you will be Lions, and devour
A valiant Man, only in love to blood;
We'll do our beſt to ſcowre your filthy den,
Happen what will to us.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Gallant Xantippus.
No more, no more o' this, if y' are my Friend;
You torture me more than theſe Men can do,
For I ſhall glory in what they inflict.
But I ſink down under your griefs and dangers▪
I would not for the world loſe this occaſion
Of winning Glory to myſelf and Rome.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Go, carry him away, and torture him.

sp.speaker: Xan.
sp.l: E're I will bear it, I'll be tortur'd with him.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Was ever ſuch amazing inſolence?

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: 'Tis well we are behind hand with his pay.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: He puts a bloody croſs on his accounts.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: 'Tis the beſt piece o' ſervice he e're did us.
sp.stage: After a Fight within, enter an Officer.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: My Lords, take ſpeedy courſe to ſave yourſelves
And the whole City, or it will be loſt.
The Spartan General has beat your Guards,
And finding he wants ſtrength to fight the Town,
He has let in part o' the Roman Troops,
Commanded by a warlike Roman Virgin,
Contracted as they ſay to Regulus.
And ſhe's come hither to revenge her Lover.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: Why, what a bold black Traytor is this Spartan?

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: My Lord, I doubt we are the Traytors now,
The beaten Party always are the Traytors.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: The beaten Party? has he got all Carthage!

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Oh! no! he's only Maſter of one Gate,
Which I believe he keeps for his retreat.
But he has ſtrength enough to do great miſchief,
Unleſs prevented.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: We will put a ſtop to't.
Where's Regulus?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: He's forc'd out of our hands.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Before he was tormented?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Well, all the better, he cannot harm us.
Go to the Spartan General, and tell him,
We ſay, he has committed a high fault,
His King and Country would ſeverely puniſh,
Should we complain of him; but for the ſake
Of his paſt ſervices we greatly love him.
If he will quickly leave the Town in peace,
And return home, all this ſhall be forgot;
We will provide him every thing he wants,
Money and Shipping.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I will let him know't.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: I will take care the Shipping ſhall be rotten,
And he ſhall ſink, perhaps in ſight of Carthage.

div.head: SCENE A Street in Carthage.
div.stage: Enter Xantippus, Fulvia, and her Women.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: Oh! noble Virgin, in whoſe ſacred breaſt,
The heart of the great Regulus is lodg'd.
Can you forgive the cruel Sacriledge
I have committed againſt him and you?
But I repent and have made ſome atonement.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: I am not able, Sir, to anſwer you.
My Soul is torn with tortur'd Regulus,
For I am told, we come too late to ſave him.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: It is too true.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: Is he alive or dead?

sp.speaker: Xan.
sp.l: He lives, and has the joy to know y're here.
I told it him, I did not think it ſafe
To bring you to him, e're he was prepar'd,
Leſt the ſurprize ſhou'd ſcatter all his Spirits.
And ſtill I am afraid the enterview
Will harm you both.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: Sir, this ſhort enterview,
Is all the wealth we hope for in this world;
And to be hinder'd of it, all the harm
That can befall us now: if you repent
The ill y'ave done us, heap no more upon us.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: The Heavens forbid. Well you ſhall have your will.
He's nearer than you think, open the door.

div.head: The SCENE is drawn, and Regulus is diſcover'd fitting in a Chair bloody.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: Oh! here's my Lord, all over wounds and blood.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: And have I liv'd to ſee my Fulvia?
Thou bringſt me joy, can heal a thouſand wounds,
Wou'dſt thou not weep; but if thou weep'ſt, my Dear,
Thou wilt ſet all my wounds bleeding afreſh.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: Can any eye ſee this, and not burſt out
In tears and blood? your barbarous Murderers
Have found a luxury in torturing you;
You are all over wounds.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Oh! no, my Love!
My Soul's all over pleaſure. Had I wounds
In Conſcience or in Honor, I indeed
Were a poor creaturre fit to be lamented;
But as I am, I'm to be envied.
I have a Conſcience which I would not change,
For all the Crowns on earth; and I have Honor,
Will live unrivall'd to Eternity;
And in my arms I've my dear Fulvia.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: And at your feet your weeping enemy,
Asking your pardon, and adoring you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Can there be then a happier man than I?
I have ſome wounds, it is no wonder ſure,
A Soldier ſhou'd have wounds, and theſe I ſought.
They give eternal life to my renown;
To me but a few pains, which now methinks,
Are gone, my Fulvia has heal'd 'em all.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: No, no, you ſay this to deceive my ſorrow
I ſee your Agonies, Convulſions,
And feel 'em too; they tear my veins and nerves,
And I ſhall die without revenging you.
I did not doubt but to have offer'd up
This Town, a burning Victim to your Ghoſt;
A glory to which I had greateſt right,
For by your ſuff'rings I have higheſt wrong.
Now all this wealth I muſt bequeath to others.
But for my ſuff'rings I have great rewards,
Since I in life have Regulus's love,
And in Elizium ſhall poſſeſs himſelf.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: For ever dear—But do not haſten thither
By dangerous ways; harm not thy beauteous ſelf,
Leſt I ſhou'd loſe thee too, in the next world.
Dark is the paſſage to't, the cleareſt paths,
Are Vertue and Obedience to the Gods,
If 'tis their pleaſure, ſuffer life a while.
A little time in this ſhort life is much,
But it is nothing in eternity.
Some days cut off from thence, will not be miſs'd.
I'll wait the coming of thy lovely ſhade,
At th' entrance of Elizium, which to me,
Will not be an Elizium till thou com'ſt.
I'm going, weep not, Fulvia, for no man
Can live with greater pleaſure than I dye.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: He's gone! he's gone! oh! thou accurſed Carthage!
May'ſt thou abhor and ſcorn all Honor, Virtue,
Piety, Faith, till thou art ſcorn'd by all.
May'ſt thou do Villanies may deſerve hanging,
And then be fond of Tyrants that ſhall hang thee.
Ha! I'm not well, I burn, and my brain's ſick;
All nature's ſick, the frightned day ſtarts back;
Abortive night is born before its time.
Some horrid thing is done, what is the news?

sp.speaker: Xan.
sp.l: Alas! ſhe raves! ſorrow has hurt her ſence!

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: I'm told the Conſuls murder'd, is it true?
I ſaw him lately, what's become of him?

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo alas, here's a great Spirit broke.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: I'm to be married to him, I'll have him,
Though he be dead! Dead? no, he's but aſleep.
The Bridegroom ſleep before the Brides, abed,
Oh! fie upon't! I'll make him bluſh to morrow.
Undreſs, undreſs me Ladies, quickly, ſoftly,
I'll ſteal to him, and never waken him,
Then i'th' morning I will riſe a Virgin,
And we'll all laugh him out o' countenance, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Xan.
sp.l: How does ſhe mix together grief and mirth?
Ah? what confuſion's in this noble mind?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: How pale and cold he is? like a Moon beam
In a clear froſty night, oh! he will ſtarve me.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: Remove from hence the body, it diſturbs her.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: Warm, warm him ſome body. Ha! he is gone!
Then he is taken Pris'ner once again,
When he had paid his Ranſom with his blood.
Oh! treacherous inſatiable Villains!
Can nothing ſatisfie your thirſt of blood.
I'll after 'em, my Sword, my Bow, my Horſe;
Purſue, purſue, e're they are got to Carthage.

sp.speaker: Xan.
sp.l: Follow, and hold her, leſt ſhe harm herſelf.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Away, away, my Lord, the Winds blow fair.
Both from the Heavens, and the Senate-houſe.
The Senate give you leave to return home,
Order you Money, and all things you need.
They ſent this Officer, to expreſs their pleaſure▪
sp.stage: Enter an Officer, who gives Xantippus Papers.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: I thankfully accept the Senates ſavor,
And will not give 'em trouble many days.
Wilt thou go with me?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Will I ſtay behind?
If thou ſhou'dſt ſink in Seas, I'd follow thee;
Mount to the Heavens, if I ſtay behind,
It ſhall not be my fault; I will ſhake off
The luggage of this body to be with thee.
I've more good news, my Father will go with us.
And is providing ſhipping.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: Excellent Man!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: His care is needful, for he has diſcover'd
A horrible contrivance of ill men,
To ſink thee and thy Troops, in rotten Ships.

sp.speaker: Xan.
sp.l: Oh! wicked place! well I will ſink this Town;
I'll take thy Father and thyſelf away,
Whoſe Piety binds up the hands of Heaven;
Then Vengeance will have liberty to ſtrike.
And I, my Love, ſhall need your Piety,
To guard me from the anger of the Gods.
I've ruin'd a moſt noble pair of Lovers,
The divine Regulus and Fulvia.
I greatly fear her ſorrow and his blood.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.l: You did not ſhed his blood but fought to ſave it.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I did; and I will ſave his body
From any farther barb'rous violence;
I will convey it to his Camp with Honor.
And lovely Fulvia, dear, ſhall be your care.
Alas, ſhe needs it, for her ſence is gone.

sp.speaker: Eliſ.
sp.l: I will my Love.

sp.speaker: Xant.
sp.l: And then we will to Sparta,
And take up all our joy in Love and Vertue.
In theſe thou wilt find happineſs enough.
Regulus found it ſo in ſpite of torments.
Vertue! thy joys no fortune can oppreſs;
Vice! thou art wretched ſpite of all ſucceſs.
The aid of fortune is to Vertue vain;
To Vice a curſe, and more augments the bane.

div.head: BOOKS lately Printed for J. Knapton, viz.

list.head: MR. Tho. Shadwells Works, late Poet I aureat, containing theſe Plays following, to be had bound up, or ſingle
All Mr. Dryden 's Works in four Volumes, Mr. Lee 's, and Mr. Otway 's, in one Volume each; or the Play ſingle.
list.item: The Hiſtory of the Inquiſition of G • a.
